title: Can you solve the rogue AI riddle? - Dan Finkel

multiple-choice.question: A hostile artificial intelligence called NIM has taken over the world's computers, and you're the only person skilled enough to shut it down. You're floating in a raft on top of 25 stories of electrified water. What is the minimum number of stories you can lower the water level by on your first turn?
If you lower the water level to 2, what is the only move you can make on your next turn?

options.label: A
options.text: Lower the water level by 1 story

options.label: B
options.text: Lower the water level by 3 stories

options.label: C
options.text: Lower the water level by 4 stories

options.label: D
options.text: Raise the water level by 1 story

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the principle that determines whether a water level is winning or losing?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of stories above a losing level

options.label: B
options.text: The number of stories below a winning level

options.label: C
options.text: The number of moves it takes to reach a losing level

options.label: D
options.text: The number of winning levels above a losing level

multiple-choice.question: What is the shortcut that you can use to determine the color of a level, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The levels 1, 3, and 4 stories below it

options.label: B
options.text: The levels 2, 4, and 6 stories below it

options.label: C
options.text: The levels 5, 7, and 9 stories below it

options.label: D
options.text: The levels 3, 5, and 7 stories below it

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition that you need to meet to ensure that your opponent starts on a losing level every single turn?

options.label: A
options.text: You need to lower the water level to a multiple of 7

options.label: B
options.text: You need to lower the water level to a number that is two greater than a multiple of 7

options.label: C
options.text: You need to make sure your opponent starts on a winning level every single turn

options.label: D
options.text: You need to make sure your opponent starts on a losing level every single turn

title: What a conductor actually does on stage

options.label: B
options.text: To organize the music and keep everything calm.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a sense of drama and tension on stage.

options.label: D
options.text: To simply wave a baton and look impressive.

options.label: A
options.text: To keep the rhythm and beat patterns.

options.label: B
options.text: To show where a phrase goes and indicate speed.

options.label: C
options.text: To hold the music sheet and follow the score.

options.label: D
options.text: To wave to the audience and acknowledge their applause.

options.label: A
options.text: It gives them confidence and helps them play better.

options.label: B
options.text: It destroys their confidence and makes their lives difficult.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on their playing.

options.label: D
options.text: It makes them play faster or slower.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: A calm and elegant style, with an emphasis on beautiful sound.

options.label: C
options.text: A chaotic and unpredictable style, with lots of improvisation.

options.label: D
options.text: A boring and unengaging style, with no expression.

multiple-choice.question: What is the approach to conducting jazz music, according to James Gaffigan?

options.label: A
options.text: To treat it as a classical music genre, with a focus on precision and control.

options.label: B
options.text: To make the audience want to dance, while still maintaining a sense of focus on the music.

title: The Cheerios effect

title: Why does your voice change as you get older? - Shaylin A. Schundler

options.text: The age and health of the vocal cords and the size of the larynx.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: History vs. Augustus - Alex Gendler and Peta Greenfield

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Gaius Octavius's title "Augustus" in 27 BCE?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked the beginning of a new era of peace and prosperity in Rome.

options.label: B
options.text: It granted him additional honors and solidified his position as the leader of Rome.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a title given to him by the Roman people as a symbol of their gratitude.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a title he chose for himself as a symbol of his power.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the civil war that tore Rome apart after Julius Caesar's death?

options.label: A
options.text: The corrupt oligarchs in the Senate wanted to overthrow Octavius and take power for themselves.

options.label: B
options.text: Octavius joined his general Mark Antony in starting a civil war to avenge Caesar's death and increase his own power.

options.label: C
options.text: The Roman people wanted to establish a new form of government and overthrow the monarchy.

options.label: D
options.text: The Parthian Empire invaded Rome and sparked a civil war.

multiple-choice.question: What were some of the accomplishments of Augustus's rule?

options.label: A
options.text: He established consistent taxation for all provinces, improved food security for the lower classes, and constructed many public buildings.

options.label: B
options.text: He destroyed the Roman Republic and established a dictatorship.

options.label: C
options.text: He waged endless conquest and expanded Rome's frontiers in all directions.

options.label: D
options.text: He exiled many people on vague charges and restricted citizens' personal lives.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Augustus's legacy?

options.label: A
options.text: He established a tradition of civic virtue and a professional army that expanded Rome's frontiers.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a good emperor who brought peace and prosperity to Rome.

options.label: C
options.text: He was a tyrant who destroyed the Roman Republic and established a dictatorship.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a military leader who expanded Rome's frontiers and established a new form of government.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main argument of the prosecution in the trial of Augustus?

options.label: A
options.text: Augustus was a good emperor who brought peace and prosperity to Rome.

options.label: B
options.text: Augustus was a tyrant who destroyed the Roman Republic and established a dictatorship.

options.label: C
options.text: Augustus's accomplishments were too many to name, and he was a model public servant.

options.label: D
options.text: Augustus's legacy speaks for itself, and he was a great leader who expanded Rome's frontiers.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The sun will lose its energy, causing the Earth's rotation to slow down.

options.label: D
options.text: The sun will remain stable, with no effect on the Earth's climate.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Rocket Propulsion

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what would be the effect of using a large object, such as an asteroid, to move the Earth's orbit away from the sun?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The Earth's magnetic field may weaken, making it more vulnerable to solar radiation.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

title: Why don’t poisonous animals poison themselves? - Rebecca D. Tarvin

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why bombardier beetles can survive their own toxic secretions?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a special gland that neutralizes the poison.

options.label: B
options.text: They store the ingredients for their poison in separate chambers.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a special membrane that protects their internal tissues.

options.label: D
options.text: They have a unique enzyme that breaks down the poison.

multiple-choice.question: How do poison dart frogs accumulate their bitter-tasting compounds called alkaloids?

options.label: A
options.text: They synthesize them in their own bodies.

options.label: B
options.text: They absorb them from the soil.

options.label: C
options.text: They consume small arthropods like mites and ants.

options.label: D
options.text: They produce them through photosynthesis.

multiple-choice.question: What prevents poison frogs from poisoning themselves?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a special enzyme that breaks down the poison.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a genetic mutation that makes them resistant.

options.label: C
options.text: The molecular target of the neurotoxic alkaloid is altered.

options.label: D
options.text: They have a special membrane that protects their internal tissues.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the evolutionary arms race between toxic animals and their predators/prey?

options.label: A
options.text: The toxic animals become more toxic, while their predators/prey become more resistant.

options.label: B
options.text: The predators/prey become more toxic, while the toxic animals become more resistant.

options.label: C
options.text: The toxic animals and their predators/prey become equally toxic and resistant.

options.label: D
options.text: The toxic animals and their predators/prey become extinct.

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique adaptation of horned lizards that allows them to consume harvester ants without being harmed?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a special gland that neutralizes the ant's venom.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Can you solve the Mondrian squares riddle? - Gord Hamilton

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of the two-fold challenge presented by Dutch artist Piet Mondrian's abstract, rectangular paintings?

options.label: A
options.text: To cover a square canvas with non-overlapping rectangles as quickly as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: To cover a square canvas with non-overlapping rectangles and get as low a score as possible.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a two-fold challenge by dividing the canvas into two equal parts.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a two-fold challenge by dividing the canvas into two unequal parts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the lowest score that can be achieved on an 8x8 canvas?

options.label: A
options.text: To use a wide range of rectangle sizes.

options.label: B
options.text: To use a narrow range of rectangle sizes that add up to the total area of the canvas.

options.label: C
options.text: To use identical rectangles of the same size.

options.label: D
options.text: To use rectangles with odd areas.

multiple-choice.question: What is the total area of a 4x4 canvas?

options.label: A
options.text: To divide the canvas into two equal parts.

options.label: B
options.text: To use a wide range of rectangle sizes.

options.label: C
options.text: To try different combinations of rectangle sizes and see what works.

options.label: D
options.text: To use identical rectangles of the same size.

title: How I turn negative online comments into positive offline conversations

options.text: He responded with more hate messages.

options.text: He developed an unexpected coping mechanism.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: He quit making content and went into hiding.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the eardrum in the auditory system?

options.text: To amplify sound waves before they reach the middle ear

options.label: D
options.text: To block sound waves from entering the ear canal

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The cochlear fluid

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D
